Question 2

dist_tbl <- flights |>
  filter(month == 1) |>
  group_by(carrier) |>
  summarise(
    mean_distance = mean(distance, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd_distance = sd(distance, na.rm = TRUE)
  ) |>
  arrange(mean_distance)

dist_tbl

Question 3

Finding out which carriers have a standard deviation with 0 or NA.

# Show carriers where sd_distance is NA
dist_tbl |> filter(is.na(sd_distance))
# A tibble: 1 × 3
  carrier mean_distance sd_distance
  <chr>           <dbl>       <dbl>
1 OO                733          NA
# Show carriers where sd_distance is 0
dist_tbl |> filter(sd_distance == 0)
# A tibble: 4 × 3
  carrier mean_distance sd_distance
  <chr>           <dbl>       <dbl>
1 YV                229           0
2 F9               1620           0
3 AS               2402           0
4 HA               4983           0

If the standard deviation is NA, this happens when a carrier has only one flight in January. The standard deviation requires at least two data points to be computed. if the standard deviation is 0, this happens when all flights for that carrier have the same distance, leading to zero variation.

Question 4

dep_delay_df <- flights |>
  group_by(month, carrier) |>
  summarise(avg_dep_delay = mean(dep_delay, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop") |>
  pivot_wider(names_from = carrier, values_from = avg_dep_delay)  # Reshape to wide format

Question 5

# Calculate the proportion of flights that departed late but arrived on or before time
delayed_but_on_time <- flights |>
  summarise(
    total_flights = n(),
    count_delayed_but_on_time = sum(dep_delay > 0 & arr_delay <= 0, na.rm = TRUE)
  ) |>
  mutate(proportion = count_delayed_but_on_time / total_flights)

delayed_but_on_time$proportion
[1] 0.1052391

Question 6

Identifying the routes that more than one airline flies.

multi_airline_routes <- flights |>
  group_by(origin, dest) |>
  summarise(num_airlines = n_distinct(carrier), .groups = "drop") |>
  filter(num_airlines > 1)

multi_airline_routes
# A tibble: 128 × 3
   origin dest  num_airlines
   <chr>  <chr>        <int>
 1 EWR    ATL              4
 2 EWR    AUS              2
 3 EWR    BDL              2
 4 EWR    BNA              2
 5 EWR    BOS              3
 6 EWR    BWI              2
 7 EWR    CHS              2
 8 EWR    CLE              2
 9 EWR    CLT              3
10 EWR    CVG              2
# ℹ 118 more rows

Calculate the average arrival delay for each airline

route_delays <- flights |>
  inner_join(multi_airline_routes, by = c("origin", "dest")) |>
  group_by(origin, dest, carrier) |>
  summarise(avg_arr_delay = mean(arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")

route_delays
# A tibble: 343 × 4
   origin dest  carrier avg_arr_delay
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>           <dbl>

10 EWR    BNA   WN              -2.13
# ℹ 333 more rows

Finding the names of these airlines

route_delays_with_names <- route_delays |>
  inner_join(airlines, by = "carrier") |>
  select(origin, dest, name, avg_arr_delay)

Identify the airline with the worst and best average arrival delay for each route

route_performance <- route_delays |>
  group_by(origin, dest) |>
  summarise(
    worst_airline = carrier[which.max(avg_arr_delay)],
    worst_delay = max(avg_arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    best_airline = carrier[which.min(avg_arr_delay)],
    best_delay = min(avg_arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) |>
  inner_join(airlines, by = c("worst_airline" = "carrier")) |>
  rename(worst_airline_name = name) |>
  inner_join(airlines, by = c("best_airline" = "carrier")) |>
  rename(best_airline_name = name)

route_performance
# A tibble: 128 × 8
   origin dest  worst_airline worst_delay best_airline best_delay
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>               <dbl> <chr>             <dbl>
 1 EWR    ATL   EV                  19.5  9E               -6.25 
 2 EWR    AUS   UA                   4.28 WN              -11.2  
 3 EWR    BDL   UA                  22.6  EV                6.78 
 4 EWR    BNA   EV                  17.7  WN               -2.13 
 5 EWR    BOS   B6                   6.87 EV               -4.01 
 6 EWR    BWI   EV                  20.1  WN                5.95 
 7 EWR    CHS   EV                  16.2  UA              -14    
 8 EWR    CLE   UA                   5.97 EV               -3.71 
 9 EWR    CLT   EV                  20.5  US                0.920
10 EWR    CVG   EV                  21.2  9E                1.40 
# ℹ 118 more rows
# ℹ 2 more variables: worst_airline_name <chr>, best_airline_name <chr>

Identify the route with the greatest difference between best and worst performing airlines

largest_difference_route <- route_performance |>
  mutate(delay_diff = worst_delay - best_delay) |>
  arrange(desc(delay_diff)) |>
  slice(1)

largest_difference_route
# A tibble: 1 × 9
  origin dest  worst_airline worst_delay best_airline best_delay
  <chr>  <chr> <chr>               <dbl> <chr>             <dbl>
1 JFK    ATL   EV                    128 9E                 1.40
# ℹ 3 more variables: worst_airline_name <chr>, best_airline_name <chr>,
#   delay_diff <dbl>

Let’s examine flight counts and variability in delays for this route

reason_for_difference <- flights |>
  filter(origin == largest_difference_route$origin, dest == largest_difference_route$dest) |>
  group_by(carrier) |>
  summarise(
    num_flights = n(),
    mean_arr_delay = mean(arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd_arr_delay = sd(arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) |>
  inner_join(airlines, by = "carrier") |>
  arrange(desc(mean_arr_delay))

reason_for_difference
# A tibble: 3 × 5
  carrier num_flights mean_arr_delay sd_arr_delay name                    
  <chr>         <int>          <dbl>        <dbl> <chr>                   
1 EV                1         128            NA   ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
2 DL             1874           6.34         42.3 Delta Air Lines Inc.    
3 9E               55           1.40         18.0 Endeavor Air Inc.

The main reason for this is due to the extreme differences in flight frequency. Airlines with fewer flights may have skewed delayed statistics due to extreme cases.

Question 7

Identifying missing values and typos.

# Function to check for missing values
missing_values <- colSums(is.na(dataset1))

# Function to check for typos in categorical variables
find_typos <- function(column, valid_values) {
  unique(column[!(column %in% valid_values)])
}

# Define valid values for categorical columns
valid_genders <- c("male", "female")
valid_disease_status <- c("diseased", "healthy")
valid_smoker <- c("yes", "no")
valid_exercise <- c("none", "occasional", "regular")

# Check for typos
gender_typos <- find_typos(dataset1$gender, valid_genders)
disease_typos <- find_typos(dataset1$disease_status, valid_disease_status)
smoker_typos <- find_typos(dataset1$smoker, valid_smoker)
exercise_typos <- find_typos(dataset1$exercise, valid_exercise)

# Display results
list(
  missing_values = missing_values,
  gender_typos = gender_typos,
  disease_typos = disease_typos,
  smoker_typos = smoker_typos,
  exercise_typos = exercise_typos
)
$missing_values
            id            age         gender         height         weight 
             0              0              0              2              0 
    blood_type disease_status    cholesterol        glucose         smoker 
             0              0              0              3              0 
      exercise         income      education         region marital_status 
             0              0              0              0              0 

$gender_typos
[1] "femal"

$disease_typos
[1] "Healthy"
